wordpressPost.title: At Work: 6 Tips on Better Thinking
wordpressPost.content:
One of the endlessly handy tips you’re likely to pick up in a yoga class is the concept of Monkey Mind. For most of us, it’s a painfully familiar visual: monkeys jumping around in your brain, mischievously distracting you from thought to thought’and making it practically impossible to sustain focus, never mind a brilliant idea.

Despite the ubiquitous noise, and because of it, we’d like to tame the monkeys with 6 tips on What Works for Better Thinking.
Pro Procrastination
No, you may not nap all day and call it productive, but a little spacey thinking is a good thing, according to work guru Adam Grant. When you procrastinate, you’re more likely to let your mind wander. That gives you a better chance of stumbling onto the unusual and spotting unexpected patterns, explains Grant, best-selling author and WeSpire advisor. Our first ideas, after all, are usually our most conventional.

When you procrastinate, you’re more likely to let your mind wander. That gives you a better chance of stumbling onto the unusual and spotting unexpected patterns”

As Georgetown professor Cal Newport says, there’s an absurd attack on concentration in many offices.
What Works:
Instead of rushing to finish tasks ahead of schedule, allow enough time to return to your work, before it’s time to ship.
Next time you’re standing in line, resist the urge to check your phone. Instead, take some deep breaths and simply do that one thing: Stand. In. Line.
Whether it’s a shower, a walk, a meditation break, or kneading dough, be sure you find time of your own. Create space in your life, moments when you’re not tied to your devices, so you have that extra space to find connections between ideas. Productivity guru Scott Barry Kaufman says. Even five minutes.
If your work space is abuzz, grab headphones and tune out the noise. Create opportunities for deep work by setting a schedule and sticking to it.
Professor Newport’s email mantra: Don’t answer every single one. Especially if nothing really good will happen if you respond and nothing really bad will happen if you don’t.
Change up your Scenery: go outside for a walk, weather permitting.
Recommended Reading:
Why I Taught Myself to Procrastinate
Why People Get their Best Ideas in the Shower
Deep Work: Rules for Focused Success in a Distracted World, by Cal Newport (reviewed here by Kate Bachelder)
At WeSpire we can’t get enough of our customers’ big ideas. We love making sure they’re successful, and we’re always looking for new thoughts on how to make positive impact.
What do you do to set your mind free?
